Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: An angry client is loudly criticising a cut moments before the salon is due to close.
Story: I glanced at the clock, feeling the weight of the day pressing on my shoulders. My husband’s text buzzed on my phone: “Rough day. Can’t wait to see you.” I knew he’d want to talk, to unwind, and I wanted to be there for him, to listen and reassure him like a good wife should. But just as I was about to close up the salon, a client stormed in, her voice sharp and accusing. “This cut is nothing like what I asked for!” she snapped, drawing the attention of everyone left in the shop. My heart pounded. I could see the disappointment in her eyes, and I knew I had to fix it, to make her feel heard and valued—my reputation depended on it. But every minute I spent here was a minute I wasn’t with my husband, offering the comfort he needed. Torn between soothing a client and supporting my partner, I felt the tension knotting in my chest, unsure which role to answer first.
